sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Consider the nonlinear equation f(x) = x^3 - 3x - 5. Using Newton-Raphson method, find the root of f(x) correct to four decimal places, starting with x0 = 2.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 3x - 5. The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 3

The Newton-Raphson formula is:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We start with x0 = 2. We'll iterate the process until we reach the desired accuracy of four decimal places.

Iteration 1:
x1 = 2 - ( (2^3 - 3*2 - 5) / (3*(2^2) - 3) )
x1 = 2 - ( (-1) / (9) )
x1 = 2 + 1/9
x1 ≈ 2.1111

Iteration 2:
x1 = 2.1111
x2 = x1 - ( (x1^3 - 3*x1 - 5) / (3*(x1^2) - 3) )
x2 ≈ 2.0946

Iteration 3:
x1 = 2.0946
x2 = x1 - ( (x1^3 - 3*x1 - 5) / (3*(x1^2) - 3) )
x2 ≈ 2.0946

Since the result did not change after the third iteration (up to four decimal places), we can conclude that the root of the function f(x) = x^3 - 3x - 5 is approximately x ≈ 2.0946.
